_meta.note: Readable lore content for Guard's Journal Pages, Quest Notices, Training Manual Pages, and other narrative items

guards_journal_pages.text: The eastern wall buckled today. Captain says we hold until reinforcements arrive. Nobody believes reinforcements are coming. The men talk of desertion. I talk of duty. We're both lying.
Found fresh rat tracks in the grain stores. Better than what we feared. The whispers from below have stopped. I don't know if that's good or bad. Sleep eludes me.
My name is harder to remember each day. The dungeon takes more than your life. It takes your certainty. Jenkins swears he never had a brother. I remember his brother's funeral. Which of us is right?
The new recruits don't understand the rules here. Don't trust the echoes. Don't follow the lights. Don't open doors that weren't there yesterday. By the time they learn, half will be gone.
We sealed the lower passages. Whatever came through... it wore Sergeant Hale's face but couldn't remember his daughter's name. We did what we had to. The screaming stopped around midnight.

Heard music from the forgotten chapel. Beautiful, terrible music. Three guards went to investigate. Only two came back, and they won't speak. The third is still down there, they say, conducting an invisible choir.
The cold here isn't natural. It remembers things. Frostbite patterns on Miller's hands spelled out his grandmother's dying words. He never told anyone those words. The dungeon knew anyway.
I found my own journal entry from tomorrow. It describes my death in the Bell Tower. I'm not going near the Bell Tower. I'm not going near the Bell Tower. I'm not going—

The armory doors opened by themselves last night. Nothing was taken, but everything was moved. Swords face the opposite direction. Shields hang upside down. The arrangement spells something in a language we don't recognize. We put everything back. It happened again tonight.

Private Hayes claims the statue in the courtyard blinks when no one is watching. We laughed at him. Then Marcus caught it mid-blink. Now we all see it. The statue used to face east. This morning it faced the barracks. We don't look at it anymore.

The mess hall served stew tonight. Same recipe as always. But Thompson says it tasted like his mother's cooking. Williams says it tasted like his wedding feast. I tasted the meal I had the day before I came here. We all ate something different. The pot was the same.

The northern gallery collapsed. Seven guards trapped below. We dug for three days. Found six bodies and eight skulls. The extra skull wore a guard helm from our battalion. It wasn't old. We stopped counting.

Protocol says patrol in pairs. Anderson and I stick together. Tonight I turned around and Anderson was gone. But I heard his footsteps. I followed them for an hour. The footsteps came from in front of me. I was following myself.

Found a locked chest in the old barracks. Key was on a chain around my neck. I don't remember putting it there. Inside the chest: my orders, dated next month, assigning me to a post that doesn't exist. My signature is already on them.

The flowers in the guard captain's quarters bloomed overnight. Beautiful crimson petals. Perfect formations. The captain has been dead for two years. The flowers smell like his pipe tobacco. They turn to face whoever enters the room.

This is my last entry as a guard. Tomorrow I join the Silent Watch—those who guard the places that must never be disturbed. We don't speak. We don't write. We don't remember our names. When you forget who you are, the dungeon can't take what's already gone. Goodbye.

quest_notices.title: WANTED: The Glasswork Thief
quest_notices.text: A thief has been stealing crystallized souls from the Glasswork Cathedral. The thief leaves no footprints, casts no shadow, and breathes no air. Approach with caution. Do not look directly at their reflection.

quest_notices.title: URGENT: Retrieve the Singing Blade
quest_notices.text: The Singing Blade was lost in the Harmony Vault three years ago. It still sings. Every full moon, we hear it calling for its wielder. The wielder has been dead for five years. Retrieve the blade. Stop the singing. Please.

quest_notices.title: CONTRACT: Clear the Flooded Archives
quest_notices.text: The lower archives flooded during the equinox. Something in the water is rewriting the books. Historical records now describe events that never happened. Wars we never fought. Kings we never crowned. Drain the archives before the false histories become true.

quest_notices.title: BOUNTY: The Clockwork Deserter
quest_notices.text: A clockwork soldier has gone rogue in the mechanism halls. It refuses to stop marching. It refuses to acknowledge the war ended. It refuses to accept that its battalion was destroyed 40 years ago. Approach with compassion. Destroy with efficiency.

quest_notices.title: EXPEDITION: Map the Shifting Corridors
quest_notices.text: The eastern corridors rearrange themselves nightly. We need accurate maps to establish stable supply routes. Previous cartographers have submitted maps of rooms that don't exist, hallways that loop in impossible ways, and one map that was just the word 'LEAVE' written 700 times.

quest_notices.title: EMERGENCY: Silence the Prayer Bells
quest_notices.text: The prayer bells in the Sunken Oratory ring backwards at midnight. Those who hear them experience memories that don't belong to them. Last week, Guard Thompson remembered dying in the great fire of 1847. Thompson was born in 1852. Stop the bells. Forget what they showed you.

quest_notices.title: COMMISSION: Recover the Weeping Portrait
quest_notices.text: The portrait of Lady Ashdown hangs in the Crimson Gallery. At dawn, it weeps tears of blood. At dusk, it smiles. At midnight, it turns to face the door. Recover it for the family. Do not look at it during the transition hours. The last courier looked. He's still standing in the gallery, facing the wrong direction.

quest_notices.title: ALERT: Contain the Echo Chamber
quest_notices.text: The Echo Chamber in the Resonance Wing has developed consciousness. It repeats conversations from fifty years ago, perfectly. It argues with itself using the voices of the dead. Last week it called my name. I've never been to the Resonance Wing. Seal the chamber. Destroy the recordings. Don't listen to what it says about you.

quest_notices.title: POSTING: Apprentice Needed for Soul Binding
quest_notices.text: Seeking brave apprentice to assist with binding malevolent spirits. Previous experience unnecessary—previous apprentices didn't have any either. Must be comfortable with screaming. Must not be bothered by the smell of burnt hair. Must be able to work independently after the Master inevitably gets possessed. Housing provided in the Master's former quarters.

quest_notices.title: REQUEST: Find the Merchant's Daughter
quest_notices.text: My daughter Elisa descended into the dungeon six months ago, seeking adventure. She sends letters weekly. They arrive before she writes them. Last letter described her triumphant return next Tuesday. It's Friday now. She still hasn't come back. Find her. Bring her home. Tell her we got her letters. Tell her we read them all. Please.

quest_notices.title: DANGER: Do Not Enter the Gilt Hall
quest_notices.text: This is not a bounty. This is a warning. The Gilt Hall on the third sublevel is not safe. The gold coating on the walls is not decorative. It's a seal. Something is trapped behind the gold. It's getting out. The coating grows thinner every day. When you can see through the gold, run. When you can see what's behind the gold, you're already too late.

quest_notices.title: INVESTIGATION: The Duplicate District
quest_notices.text: The southern wing has duplicated itself. There are now two identical southern wings, occupying the same space. Guards report being in both simultaneously. Merchants set up shop in one wing and somehow made sales in the other. Scholar Pemberton entered the duplicate wing and met himself leaving. They both filed the same report. Investigate this phenomenon. Determine which wing is real. Determine if it matters.

training_manual_pages.title: Chapter 3: Footwork Fundamentals
training_manual_pages.text: A warrior's feet are their foundation. The Shifting Tiles exercise teaches recruits to trust their balance, not their eyes. Advanced students learn that some tiles were never solid to begin with. Do not question the gaps in your memory of this exercise.

training_manual_pages.title: Chapter 7: Combat Awareness
training_manual_pages.text: In dungeon combat, your enemy is not always what you see. Watch for tells: unnatural breathing patterns, shadows falling the wrong direction, wounds that heal backwards. If your opponent doesn't bleed, retreat immediately. If your opponent bleeds upward, you're already dead.

training_manual_pages.title: Chapter 11: Survival Protocols
training_manual_pages.text: Three rules for dungeon survival: 1) Never eat food that remembers being alive. 2) Never trust a door that apologizes. 3) Never follow the sound of your own voice calling from the dark. These rules have kept soldiers alive for generations. The soldiers who broke them are still here. Technically.

training_manual_pages.title: Chapter 15: Mental Fortitude
training_manual_pages.text: The dungeon tests your mind as much as your body. Hallucinations are common. If you see your dead comrades, ignore them. If you see yourself, kill it before it sees you. If you see nothing at all for more than an hour, you're in the Void Halls. Start walking north. Never stop.

training_manual_pages.title: Appendix C: Emergency Procedures
training_manual_pages.text: If you hear the bells toll thirteen times, you have approximately four minutes to reach consecrated ground. If you see a door marked with a red hand, do not open it—the hand marks those who opened it before. If you smell roses in the lower levels, hold your breath and run. The roses haven't existed for 80 years.

training_manual_pages.title: Chapter 5: Weapon Maintenance
training_manual_pages.text: Clean your blade after every encounter. Not for the blood—blood is temporary. Clean it for the memories. Weapons used in the dungeon remember what they've killed. A neglected blade starts cutting things you didn't aim at. Start cutting things you weren't thinking about. Start cutting things that aren't there yet.

training_manual_pages.title: Chapter 9: Formation Fighting
training_manual_pages.text: Shield wall drills are essential for coordinated defense. Keep your line tight. Trust your brothers. Watch your flanks. If a gap opens in the wall, close it immediately. If a gap opens and you can see yourself on the other side, the drill is over. You failed. We're sorry.

training_manual_pages.title: Chapter 13: Armor Care
training_manual_pages.text: Inspect your armor daily for rust, cracks, and faces. Faces shouldn't be there, but sometimes they are—screaming mouths in the steel, weeping eyes in the rivets. This is normal for dungeon-forged armor. The faces are protective. They scream warnings. Listen to them. Never tell them to shut up.

training_manual_pages.title: Chapter 19: Advanced Techniques
training_manual_pages.text: The Seven Forms are the foundation of combat mastery. First Form: Strike. Second Form: Defend. Third Form: Counter. Fourth Form: [PAGES MISSING]. Seventh Form is forbidden. Those who learn it cannot unlearn it. They fight in their sleep. They fight their shadows. They fight the air until the air fights back.

training_manual_pages.title: Appendix F: Supernatural Encounters
training_manual_pages.text: When facing spectral opponents: silver does nothing, prayer does nothing, faith does less than nothing. What works: speaking their name incorrectly, wearing your clothes inside-out, carrying iron nails in your left boot. Why these work is classified. That they work is enough. Don't ask questions. The ghosts are listening.

scrawled_notes.text: Day 3: Found a shortcut through the old wine cellar. Day 4: Used the shortcut again, saved ten minutes. Day 5: The shortcut is getting longer. Day 6: I've been walking the shortcut for three hours. I can see both ends but I can't reach either. Day 7:

The merchant in the west hall sells memories. Not memory aids—actual memories. For 5 gold you can remember being someone else. I bought a memory of sunshine. It was worth it. I bought another. And another. I can't remember who I was before the purchases. I'm not sure I want to.

WARNING to future explorers: Do not trust the friendly ghost in corridor 7. She'll offer to guide you. She's very helpful. She'll get you exactly where you need to go. You won't like where you need to go. Her last words were an apology. They're still her last words. She's still saying them.

I've been keeping a tally of days on this wall. Today I noticed someone has been crossing them out. Just the Thursdays. Only the Thursdays are crossed out. I don't remember any Thursdays. Did I cross them out? Why only Thursdays? Why can't I remember Thursdays?

Found a room full of mirrors today. My reflection waved at me. I didn't wave back. Smart. It's trying to be friendly. Making me trust it. But I've seen what happens when you trust your reflection here. Mirror-Thompson still walks the halls, but Thompson is gone. Stay suspicious. Stay alive.

NOTICE: The stairs to the lower levels only appear on Tuesdays. They vanish at midnight. If you're still on them when they disappear, you fall into the space between floors. We can still hear the last expedition down there. They're begging for Tuesdays. It's Saturday.

The paintings in the portrait gallery are developing opinions. They critique each other. They gossip about visitors. Yesterday one asked me for help escaping its frame. I said no. This morning it was empty. The subject is loose somewhere. The frame is grateful.

To whoever finds this: The fountain in the south courtyard grants wishes. Real wishes. I wished for gold. Got gold. Wished for health. Got healthy. Wished to understand the dungeon. Now I understand. Now I can't stop understanding. The fountain is still offering wishes. Don't. Please don't.

Found a chess set in the abandoned barracks. The pieces move on their own. They're playing a game that started 80 years ago. Black is winning. White has been in check for three decades. If black wins, something happens. The pieces won't say what. They just keep playing.

List of safe places: The library (Tuesdays only). The kitchen (avoid the stew). The barracks (if you don't mind company from the walls). Nowhere else. Trust this list. I've survived here for six months by following it. The list updates itself. I don't update it. Yesterday it added 'The Mirror Hall' and I know that's wrong. The list might be compromised.

pressed_pages.text: From 'The Botanical Treatise of Dead Gardens': The thornvines in the deep archives are carnivorous, certainly, but that's not what makes them dangerous. They're literate. They read everything they catch. After 400 years of consuming scholars, they know more than most libraries. They'll answer questions if you feed them. Preferably someone else.

Catalog entry 447-B: The singing flowers of the Thorn Archive produce beautiful harmonies when properly watered. Water requirements: one part rainwater, two parts tears, three parts blood. The blood must be voluntary. The flowers can tell the difference. They always tell the difference.

Research log, Dr. Holloway: The preserved pages in the living hedges contain knowledge lost to fire and time. The hedges remember books that were never written. Poems that were never composed. My assistant claims they contain his obituary, dated next Tuesday. I told him not to worry. It's probably just one of the unwritten poems.

Entry from the Botanist's Journal: Specimen 47 - A flower from the northern gardens. Petals don't wilt. Stem continues growing. After three months, specimen has filled seven rooms. After six months, it has grown into the past. I can see it in my childhood memories now. It was always there.

Letter fragment pressed into page: '...cannot return home. The path remembers me but refuses to let me leave. I walk toward the exit but end up deeper inside. Mother, if you find this, don't come looking. The dungeon collects families. I've met three versions of Father here. None of them remember...'

Recipe card, corners burnt: 'Dungeon Bread: Use flour from the cursed millstone. Add water from the weeping well. Knead for three hours or three days (time varies by room). Bake until golden or until it screams. Serves six. Or twelve. Or none. Bread may achieve consciousness during cooling. Discourage this.'

surgeons_notes.text: Patient 23: Symptoms include chalk dust in the lungs, alabaster bones, and hardening of the major organs. Treatment: none effective. Patient claims to feel lighter each day. Patient claims to feel nothing at all. Patient is becoming a statue. Patient doesn't seem to mind.

Medical observation: The dust in the Alabaster Ward is not inert mineral. It's the powdered remains of the plague victims sealed in the walls. When inhaled, it remembers being human. It wants to be human again. It will use whatever materials are available. Recommend immediate evacuation.

Autopsy report: Cause of death determined to be 'becoming marble.' Subject's last words were 'I can see forever.' Subject's eyes had turned to polished stone. Subject's eyes are still watching. Recommend cremation. Recommend it urgently.

Surgical log, Dr. Vance: Attempted to remove the crystalline growths from Patient 89's chest cavity. Crystals regenerate faster than I can cut. Patient is conscious throughout. Patient is singing. The crystals are making her sing. She's begging me to stop but her mouth keeps singing. Abandoning procedure.

Case study: The Petrification Plague spreads through eye contact with infected stone. Victims report feeling 'heavy' before symptoms manifest. Advanced stages: skin hardens, joints lock, thoughts slow to geological pace. Terminal stage: patient achieves complete petrifaction. Cure: none discovered. Prevention: avoid the Marble Gallery.

Medical transcript: 'Doctor, I can taste colors now. The red tastes like screaming. The blue tastes like drowning. I tried to tell the nurses but they're all purple and purple tastes like forgetting. I'm forgetting how to be meat. The walls are teaching me to be stone. They're very patient teachers.'

puzzle_notes.text: The Riddle Mill's logic gates were designed by the mathematician Erasmus Cogworth. He went mad trying to create a machine that could think. He succeeded. The machine thinks constantly. It thinks about grinding. It thinks about weight. It thinks about bones. The flour it produces is not flour.

Solution to the Millstone Puzzle: Turn the wheel thrice counter-clockwise, answer the stone's question truthfully, and offer something precious. The stone asks different questions to different people. It asked me what I feared most. I lied. The stone knew. I don't have hands anymore. Don't lie to the stone.

The Lock Mechanism Treatise: The combination lock in the vault has infinite digits. Each digit is the answer to a mathematical proof. The proofs get progressively harder. Digit 47 requires understanding topology in eleven dimensions. Digit 83 asks you to prove you exist. I can't. I failed digit 83.

Cipher key found in the Archive: The encrypted texts use a substitution cipher where each letter represents a concept rather than a sound. 'A' means regret. 'T' means inevitable. When decoded, every text says the same thing. You don't want to know what it says. I decoded it anyway. It was right.

star_charts.text: Astronomical notation: The reflected stars in the Stargazer's Sump do not match any known constellations. They match constellations that will exist in 10,000 years. The water isn't reflecting the sky. It's reflecting the future. Former astronomer Hale stared too long. Now he knows when he'll die. He won't tell us the date. He doesn't have to. We can see it in his eyes.

Navigation chart, marked 'FORBIDDEN': The stars in the underground planetarium show safe routes through the dungeon. Follow the North Star to safety. Follow the Red Star to treasure. Do not follow the Black Star. The Black Star isn't on the charts. If you can see the Black Star, it can see you. It's always been able to see you.

Celestial observations, Dr. Vess: The constellation above the courtyard changes position every hour, but the hour hand on my watch hasn't moved in three days. The stars spell out words in a language I don't recognize. Yesterday I recognized one word. Today I recognize three. Tomorrow I'll understand the whole sentence. I'm afraid of what it will tell me to do.

Star map fragment: The wandering star that appears only on solstices isn't a star. It's the eye of something vast looking through a hole in reality. When you wish upon it, it wishes back. Former astrologer Kepler made a wish. It came true. Then the star's wish came true. We don't know what it wished for. Kepler won't say. He can't stop smiling.

cracked_map_scraps.text: Partial dungeon map, water-damaged. Shows three corridors that shouldn't connect. Shows a room labeled 'You Are Here' in a section you've never visited. Shows your name written in the margins in handwriting that looks like yours but isn't quite right. Previous owner unknown. Previous owner probably still here somewhere.

Fragment of a dungeon chart. The scale keeps changing—one inch equals ten feet in the upper corner, but one inch equals a mile at the bottom. The rooms are drawn in different hands. Some in ink. Some in blood. One in what appears to be charcoal, with the note: 'Drawn in the dark. Could not find light. Could not find exit. Could not find myself.'

Torn section of a floor plan. Rooms are labeled with warnings: 'SINGING WALLS—cover ears', 'BACKWARDS DOOR—do not exit', 'MIRROR HALL—close your eyes'. The last room on the map is labeled 'SAFE ROOM' with seventeen question marks after it. Someone has crossed out 'SAFE' and written 'HUNGRY' above it.

Crude map scratched onto parchment. The compass rose points in five directions. North is marked twice. A dotted line traces a path through the dungeon, then circles back on itself, then continues through walls. At the bottom, scrawled in shaky letters: 'I've been walking for three days. I'm back where I started. The rooms are different but the same. Don't trust the map. Don't trust the walls.'

Scrap of an explorer's map. Certain rooms have symbols next to them: skulls, hourglasses, broken chains. You recognize some of the rooms you've already visited, but the symbols don't match what you found there. At the edge of the map, a notation reads: 'Map changes when you're not looking. Rooms migrate. Doors lie. Trust nothing. Especially this map.'

Architect's blueprint, heavily creased: The dungeon was designed with non-Euclidean geometry. Corridors that should be parallel intersect. Staircases lead up to lower floors. The architect's note: 'Client requested impossible structure. Delivered exactly that. Building permits reality optional. Do not recommend for residential use.'

Survey map from the Cartographer's Guild: This dungeon has 47 floors. This dungeon has 4 floors. This dungeon has 470 floors. All measurements are accurate. The Guild has dissolved. The lead cartographer last seen walking into a wall that both existed and didn't. His final report: 'Space is negotiable here.'

Treasure map marked with an X: 'Dig here for riches beyond measure.' Someone has written below: 'Dug for three hours. Found another map. That map led to another map. Forty-seven maps deep now. Just found a map of my own room at home. The X is on my bed. I'm afraid to go back.'

Topographical map showing elevation changes: Level 1 is at sea level. Level 2 is at 500 feet above sea level. We're underground. These numbers are impossible. Former surveyor Brass tried to reconcile the data. He proved mathematically that the dungeon doesn't exist. The dungeon disagreed. Brass no longer exists. The dungeon remains.

Hand-drawn map on human skin (origin unknown): Routes marked in scar tissue. 'Path of Echoes' leads to screaming. 'Silent Corridor' screams louder. 'The Forgetting Path' - description missing, probably forgot it. At the center: 'The Room That Waits.' The skin is still warm. Still growing new routes. Still remembering.

old_letters.text: My dearest Elena, I write this knowing you may never read it. The dungeon grows stranger each day. The walls shift when we're not looking. Yesterday's corridors are gone today. But I wanted you to know: I think of you with every step. Your smile keeps me sane when nothing else here makes sense. If I don't return, know that you were my last true thought. -Marcus

To whoever finds this: I came here seeking treasure. I found something far more valuable - the knowledge of what I've lost. My family, my home, my name. The dungeon takes memories as payment for passage. I can barely remember why I came. But I remember this: don't follow me. - A name you can't quite read, already fading

Father, I'm sorry I left without saying goodbye. The debts were too great, the shame too heavy. I thought the dungeon's treasures could solve everything. I was wrong. The only treasure here is understanding what truly mattered. By the time you read this, I'll be deeper than words can follow. Tell mother I love her. -Your son (the name is blurred by tears)

My friend, if you're reading this, I'm likely gone. The expedition was doomed from the start. Captain Morris knew - I saw it in his eyes. We walked into this dungeon like it was just another cave. Now I know: it's alive. It watches. It learns. It remembers everyone who enters. Including you. Leave while it still lets you. -Thomas, Third Explorer's Guild

Dear Sarah, I know you told me not to go. You were right. You're always right. The fortune I sought would have meant nothing compared to the mornings with you. The dungeon shows you what you've lost. Every empty room echoes with might-have-beens. I see our future in the shadows - the life we could have had. I'm sorry. I'm so sorry. -William

To the Warden: This dungeon is not a prison. It's a test. Those who enter leave something behind - courage, hope, memory, identity. I entered with a company of twenty. Now I can only remember seven names, including my own. Soon I'll forget why I'm writing this. But I wanted to document: the dungeon isn't keeping us. We're keeping ourselves. -Warden's Predecessor

My beloved, I found your letter from ten years ago today. You wrote that you'd wait for me. But this is dated next year. The dungeon plays tricks with time. I don't know if you're waiting in my past or my future. I don't know which direction is home anymore. But I know this: I'm still coming back. Eventually. Somehow. Wait for me. -Jonathan

Brother, the monastery was wrong about this place. They said it was cursed by demons. It's not cursed. It's honest. It shows you the truth of yourself. Most people can't handle that truth. I've seen my own reflection here - all the cruelty, selfishness, and fear I've hidden behind prayers. The dungeon doesn't judge. It just reveals. Maybe that's worse. -Brother Augustine

To my past self: Don't enter this dungeon. I know you won't listen. I didn't. But I had to try. You think you're strong enough. You think you're clever enough. You're neither. None of us are. The only ones who escape are those who lose enough of themselves to fit through the cracks. I can't remember your face anymore. -Future you (you won't recognize the handwriting)

My darling daughter, by now you must be grown. Twenty years I've been in here, or so my tally marks say. But the scars on my hands are from last week, and they look decades old. Time doesn't flow right here. I may emerge to find you elderly, or not yet born. Either way, know this: every moment in this nightmare, I survived because I had you to return to. -Papa

Dear Reader, I write this as both warning and apology. I hid treasures in this dungeon - real treasures, not the dungeon's tricks. I thought it would make me legendary. Instead it made me bait. Everyone who seeks my treasure feeds the dungeon. You're feeding it now. I'm sorry. I was young and stupid and I doomed so many. The treasure is real. The cost is realer. -The Fool of Fletcher's Point

To whom it may concern: This is my resignation from the Explorer's Guild. I can no longer guide expeditions into this place. Not after what I've seen. Not after what I've become. The dungeon changes you. Not your body - your certainty. I used to know the difference between memory and dream. Now everything feels like both. I quit. I'm going home. If I can remember where that is. -Guild Master Petra

prayer_strips.text: Prayer to the Silent God: 'We pray in whispers because You listen in silence. We offer our fears because You consume them. We ask for nothing because You give the same.' The ink changes color when read aloud. Former priest Matthias read it aloud. The prayer answered. He hasn't stopped screaming prayers since.

Blessing of Safe Passage: 'May your path be straight, your steps be sure, your destination be certain.' Travelers who carry this prayer never get lost. They arrive exactly where they're meant to be. Not always where they want to be. The dungeon knows the difference.

Rite of Remembrance: 'Remember those who came before. Remember those who remain. Remember those who never were.' The names written below change every time you look away. Some names you recognize. Some names recognize you back. One name is always yours. It wasn't there yesterday.

Invocation of Protection: 'Shield us from what watches, guard us from what waits, deliver us from what knows our names.' The prayer works. Something does guard you. Something does shield you. You've never seen what it shields you from. You've heard it. Right behind the thing protecting you.

Litany of Clarity: 'Grant us clear sight to see truth, clear mind to know truth, clear voice to speak truth.' Those who recite this prayer see things as they truly are. Most go blind within minutes. Not physically. They close their eyes and refuse to open them. They've seen enough truth.

Hymn of the Depths: 'From darkness we came, to darkness we go, in darkness we find what we already know.' Sung by the choir in the abandoned chapel. The choir has been dead for decades. The singing continues. New voices join every week. Some are familiar. Some are your own from tomorrow.

Supplication for Mercy: 'We are small. We are weak. We are insignificant. Please remember this.' The dungeon accepts this prayer. It does remember. It treats you accordingly. Former knight Sir Rothland prayed for strength instead. The dungeon remembered that too. We found his armor. Still occupied. Still walking. Still strong. No longer human.

Chant of Unseeing: 'What we do not see cannot see us. What we do not name cannot name us. What we do not know cannot know us.' Those who chant this become invisible to certain entities. And to certain realities. And eventually to themselves. We can still hear them chanting. They've forgotten why.

Prayer of Last Resort: 'When all hope is gone, when all paths are closed, when all light is extinguished, we call upon—' The rest is burned away. Every copy ends the same way. Some say finishing the prayer summons help. Others say it summons something that thinks it's helping. No one who's finished the prayer can confirm which.

Devotional of the Endless Vigil: 'We watch what sleeps. We guard what dreams. We maintain what must never wake.' The temple guards recited this every hour. Then the shifts got longer. Then the guards stopped leaving. Then the guards stopped being guards. Now they're part of what they were watching. Still vigilant. Still devoted. No longer themselves.
